USD 470 students are eligible to receive school meals, Monday through Friday, regardless of whether they’re in the district’s Remote Learning Program or are participating in the Hybrid Model by alternating between on-site classes and at-home learning.

Unlike the Summer Meal Program, students must be enrolled in USD 470 and families will be charged for lunches based on their normal rate of pay. Breakfast will remain free for all students. Families who have not completed the Free/Reduced meal application are encouraged to go here or their child’s school to complete the form.

Hybrid students will take their meals home with them on their last on-site day each week. Families will be asked to pre-order the meals ahead time. Elementary parents can complete a form at their child’s Meet the Teacher appointment. Parents of secondary students will be sent an electronic form to complete prior to September 4.

For additional information, visit https://bit.ly/2EIwo8D.

USD 470 Retiree Spotlight: Monica Wiley

Monica Wiley began her career with us many years ago as a substitute teacher. Later, she worked as a classroom aide, a middle school secretary, and for the last ten years, she’s served as the secretary for IXL Elementary. Monica is known for her warm, welcoming demeanor and her meticulous organizational skills. She is very detail-orientated and task-focused - yet always took time to cheerfully engage with students, staff members, and school visitors. In fact, she treated all students as if they were her own grandchildren. While Monica has enjoyed working with everyone over the years, she is looking forward to spending more time with her husband, grandkids, and her 95-year-old mom. She’s also ready to spend more time traveling, camping, and playing pickleball! Monica, we wish you all that and more. Congratulations!

#ArkCityPROUD

USD 470 Retiree Spotlight: Lisa Demaree

Lisa Demaree has been with us since 2005. As a high school business teacher, she has served the district in a variety of ways (in addition to teaching) including designing award certificates, helping with a student store, helping with lamination, designing various products and has even taken on the monumental task of producing student agendas for grades 6-12 - over 1,000 agendas each year! Honestly, there are too many things to list but Lisa has modeled an impressive work ethic to her students and has given them the tools and confidence needed to be successful in the real world. She really values the relationships she’s formed at ACHS and is looking forward to camping and spending time on her houseboat with family and friends. We hope you have the best time, Lisa! Congrats!

USD 470 Retiree Spotlight: Marvie Davis

Marvie Davis served as a custodian and champion for children in our district since 1981! On any given day she could be found cleaning, singing, and dancing along to some loud, upbeat jams. She worked hard and played hard and her joy was nothing short of contagious. Marvie has a great love for the Chicago Cubs, traveling, and for her Jeffy Pups - who she would greet with high fives as they entered the building each day. She took care of her colleagues and students with an unmatched pride. Her sense of humor and zest for life will definitely be missed. Marvie, we hope you’re enjoying your retirement. Congratulations!

USD 470 Retiree Spotlight: Caroline Bruce

As the director of Head Start, Caroline has helped influence and shape the lives of our youngest students and their families - a role she’s enjoyed every minute of. Federal programs bring about a unique set of expectations, regulations, and guidelines but Caroline has managed everything in a way that makes it look easy. Caroline, we wish you more downtime and quality time with your family during your retirement. Congratulations!

USD 470 Retiree Spotlight: Diane Banta

Diane Banta has been with us for 37 years! Though she most recently worked as a middle school PE teacher, she has served in a number of roles over the years and has great knowledge about most subjects taught at ACMS. Diane is kind to all and always sees the best in everyone. Her favorite parts of working for USD 470 are the staff and students - a “treasure trove of jewels”. She loves people and working with middle schoolers in particular because, for them, new beginnings are happening all the time. Diane is known for spending whatever time is needed to fully understand a topic or complete a task. She expects retirement to be plenty busy as she spends more time with her large family and works on home projects. She is a Bullpup through and through and we wish her the very best in her next adventure. Congrats, Diane!

How to receive pandemic EBT:
👉 Families with children who participate in programs including SNAP food assistance, child care assistance, or TANF cash assistance: The one-time benefit will be automatically loaded onto your EBT card in the next few weeks
👉 If your family doesn't participate in SNAP, child care assistance, or TANF, but you do have kids participating in free/reduced lunch, you will be mailed a pre-loaded card in the next few weeks.

See this flier for more details! (And thanks for sharing, United Way of the Flint Hills!)

May 1 is School Lunch Hero Day and we invite you to join us in thanking our food service team members for all they do to care for our kids.

Since schools were closed due to COVID-19, a special group comprised of Chartwells K12 employees, USD 470 transportation team members and other staff members, has worked to ensure children in our community have an opportunity to eat two free meals each weekday. Who needs a cape when you have an apron?

We are excited to announce that Kansas teachers, students and parents just got a new partner in their continuous learning efforts.

Thanks to the support of Kansas Public Broadcasters, Kansas students will receive supplemental education content by way of a new television program produced by Kansas PBS stations and KSDE, and hosted by local teachers. The new program called Learning Across Kansas will begin airing the week of April 20.

Each 30-minute segment, individually produced for elementary, middle school and high school students, will feature grade-specific educational content delivered by our very own Kansas teachers who serve on KSDE’s Continuous Learning Task Force.

Teachers, students and parents/caregivers, tune in for short, fun and engaging lessons. Plus, you just might see one of your own teachers presenting!

Learn more by visiting, https://www.ksde.org/Agency/Fiscal-and-Administrative-Services/Communications-and-Recognition-Programs/Learning-Across-Kansas

Will my information be kept safe?
—
Yes. The U.S. Census Bureau is bound by law to protect the #privacy and #confidentiality of everyone who responds to the census. These protections ensure the personal information you provide cannot be used against you in any way.
—
The Census Bureau combines your responses with other responses to produce statistical summaries. It is against the law for the Census Bureau to disclose or publish any identifiable information about an individual or household.
—
By law, your personal information cannot be used against you or against anyone else by any government agency or court—and it can’t be accessed by the police department, DHS, ICE, FBI, or CIA.
—
The Census Bureau encrypts all responses submitted online and stored in its computers.
—
Learn more at KansasCounts.org.
—
